title: CATCH (Canadian Assessment of Tomography for Childhood Head injury) Rule
description: Predicts clinically significant head injuries in children aged 0-16 years to guide CT imaging decisions. Identifies high-risk factors for neurologic intervention and medium-risk factors for brain injury on CT.

parameters.name: gcs_less_than_15
parameters.description: Glasgow Coma Scale <15 at two hours after injury (HIGH RISK)

parameters.name: suspected_skull_fracture
parameters.description: Suspected open or depressed skull fracture (HIGH RISK)

parameters.name: basal_skull_fracture_signs
parameters.description: Signs of basal skull fracture (MEDIUM RISK)

result.name: catch_assessment
result.description: CATCH Rule assessment with risk stratification and CT recommendation

ranges.interpretation: Low risk for clinically significant head injury. CT not routinely indicated. Consider clinical observation and discharge planning per institutional protocols.
Medium risk for brain injury on CT. Consider CT imaging. Medium-risk factors alone identify brain injury on CT with 98.1% sensitivity. Clinical judgment should guide final decision.
High risk for neurologic intervention required. CT imaging strongly recommended. High-risk factors predict need for neurologic intervention with 100% sensitivity.

references: Osmond MH, Klassen TP, Wells GA, Correll R, Jarvis A, Joubert G, et al; Pediatric Emergency Research Canada (PERC). CATCH: a clinical decision rule for the use of computed tomography in children with minor head injury. CMAJ. 2010 Mar 9;182(4):341-8. doi: 10.1503/cmaj.091421.

Lyttle MD, Crowe L, Oakley E, Dunning J, Babl FE. Comparing CATCH, CHALICE and PECARN clinical decision rules for paediatric head injuries. Emerg Med J. 2012 Oct;29(10):785-94. doi: 10.1136/emermed-2011-200225.

Easter JS, Bakes K, Dhaliwal J, Miller M, Caruso E, Haukoos JS. Comparison of PECARN, CATCH, and CHALICE rules for children with minor head injury: a prospective cohort study. Ann Emerg Med. 2014 Aug;64(2):145-52, 152.e1-5. doi: 10.1016/j.annemergmed.2014.01.030.
formula: CATCH Rule: HIGH RISK (need for neurologic intervention) = any of: GCS <15 at 2h, suspected open/depressed skull fracture, worsening headache, irritability on exam. MEDIUM RISK (brain injury on CT) = any of: basal skull fracture signs, large scalp hematoma, dangerous mechanism.
notes: Applies to children aged 0-16 years with minor head injury
Requires initial GCS ≥13 and injury within 24 hours
Must have witnessed LOC, amnesia, disorientation, vomiting ≥2x, or irritability
High-risk factors: 100% sensitive for neurologic intervention, 70.2% specific
Medium-risk factors: 98.1% sensitive for brain injury on CT, 50.1% specific
Dangerous mechanisms: MVC >60 km/h, fall >3 feet or 5 stairs, axial load to head
Basal skull fracture signs: hemotympanum, raccoon eyes, CSF otorrhea/rhinorrhea
Large scalp hematoma: frontal, temporal, or parietal region
Consider PECARN rule as alternative - more extensively validated
Original study included 3,866 children with minor head injury
CT rate reduction: high-risk only (30.2%), any risk factor (51.9%)
Less sensitive than PECARN for children under 2 years
Should not be applied to intoxicated patients
Clinical judgment should always supplement decision rules
